column11: Review Text

column8: Great location, no tourists and a beautiful shrine
column11: Lankathilaka, this temple is even found on the Rupee banknotes and is a real gem, not far from Kandy. Together with Embekka and Ghadeladheniya, the 3 are referred to as the "3 temple loop" and can travel them well together. Lankathilaka has a huge Buddha in the shrine and a great location high on the mountain.

column8: The stone temple: the second amazing second stage of the trek of the three temples
column11: Walking through rice paddies, small tea plantations, clusters of houses, stops of small and fast buses, from where people showed us the way, from Embekka we arrived quietly to Lankatilaka, the second stop of our trek: the stone temple. There lay a surprising place and torrential rain. This Buddhist temple is considered the most magnificent architectural building created during the Gampola era, dating back to the 14th century. The temple should be from the mid-1300s and Tamil (indu) workers work there. The temple is built on a black rock (Panhalgala), where the ancient access staircase is carved, and resembles a real villa. The "house of the image" encloses the Buddha and has ceiling decorations of rare delicacy and beauty. But the visit does not end there: entering the "villa" you discover another internal building, with a mystical and mysterious atmosphere, dedicated to Hindu deities. On the outside, a long inscription in Sinhalese and Tamil is carved into the rock.

column8: Visited it on Day 2 of my TukTuk Tour
column11: I hired the same tuktuk driver who drove  me around Kandy on day 2 of my visit. He recommended 3 temples and this temple is one of them. Entrance fee is 500 LHR. It is located at the outskirts of Kandy. Like all Buddhist temples, shoes are required to be taken off. Left my shoes where I purchased the entrance ticket. There are several buildings one can visit, all of the  show statues of Buddhas plus the Stupa. Towards the back of the big white temple, one can see the big statue of Buddha inside. There are some paintings on the walls near the entrance. Note: One walks barefoot on the hot, slippery rocks, not paved lane or path. Might be a problem for elder people  with mobility issues
The most beautiful temple in all of Sri Lanka, a place rarely visited by tourists, better for us, in a town and surrounded by nature you can contemplate this wonderful temple...
I wrote about this Temple as Lankatulaka Vihara Hanessa Temple  but it should of been Lankatilaka Temple, and that is why I could not find a listing here so added a new one!

column8: Tuk Tuk ride, lot of stairs.
column11: On top of a rock which means climbing a LOT os stairs. However it is worth it. Local monk may be around to let you in for a "tour" Donation expected of course. Best to get a Tuk Tuk to get you here as goinf by bus wold be a pain

column8: Amazing historical temple near to the Kandy city
column11: This Temple was build by king Buwanekabahu IV about 700 yeras ago on a rock. It lies on a facinating landscape near to the Kandy city. Cool place ti visit. This is a Buddhist temple located in Udunuwara of Kandy, Sri Lanka. It is located on Daulagala road approximately 4 km (2.5 mi) away from Pilimatalawa junction. It is considered as the most magnificent architectural edifice created during the Gampola Kingdom of Sri Lanka. A must visit place when you are travelling to Kandy.
This Temple was build by king Buwanekabahu IV in 14 century. Lankatilaka Vihara is a Buddhist temple situated in Udunuwara of Kandy.It is beautiful Buddhist Temple.

The temple was built by King Bhuvanekabahu IV in 14th century with details and embellishments of Kandy era culture, which can be seen from the patterns at the roof of the temple especially the motif with twin cranes. The temple was built in top of a massive rock. It is still a functional temple with worshippers which we saw the local devotees who came here and did chanting by a monk. We also saw a group of school children came to this temple as study excursion. Entrance fee of LKR300 for a short visit of 30-45 mins with some understanding of Kandy Kingdom culture.

We were pleasantly surprised when we visited this temple. It is situated in a beautiful spot, above the rice fields, a lovely 30 min drive by tuk tuk from Kandy. We were the only tourists there and viewed at our ease.
Without a driver it is very hard to get to. Also the roads there aren’t the best. But a pleasant temple to walk around
This temple is near Kandy and another very old structure.  Its importance in Sri Lanka is noted as it is shown on the 500 rupee note!  The guides were very interesting and helpful.

Take the bus to Kadugaanawa/Mawanella. Get down at the Lankathilaka junction close to Pilimatalawa. .the road on the left leads to three amazing places which is education for any Srilankan who studies architecture -namely Gadaladeniya temple ,Lankathilaka temple,Ambekke Devale. Of them Lankathilaka is one unique piece of art in cement and wood which beautifully mix the traditions of South India with the home grown culture unique to Kandyan kingdom.Best for a solitary traveler or a tiny group or else the details would be lost .Worth at least one hour for this serene location.
Beautiful place with nice surrounding , buddist temple , if you want to go inside shd be go on poyadays
A very ancient buddhist temple in kandy. It is said there are lots of gems and gold given as offerings to this temple by the kings.
A beautiful drive led us to this great Buddhist temple. Once you are here it transport you to that era when it was built. Calm quite not much tourist one can have sometime to oneself.

This is a temple with a more than 300 years of history.  It is a well preserved Buddhist Temple which is about 25 km from the city of Kandy.  The approach road is very good and the temple is very attractive and located over a bare rock outcrop.  Can be ranked as a must visit place for a visitor to the Kandy town if he/she stays for about 3-4 days to see the ancient buildings and get a feeling for the pulse of the people.

This temple is one of the examples for early settlements of Kandyan kingdom dating back to 14th century. Since it is situated in a remote village, you can see the natural beauty of the environment. Fortunately this are is not urbanized. Around the temple, you can see the paddy fields, forests and rarely a vehicle. It feels like going to the Kandyan era. There's a large rock-writing which was written in both Sinhalese and Tamil. The main Buddha image house has a Buddha statue and paintings dating back to Kandyan era. Recommended for family trips with kids. This place has a value of archeology and history. 1.5 - 2 hours will be enough to spend. Access from Colombo - Kandy main road is very easy. If you are using public transport, get down at Pilimatalawa. Since the temple is located 4.5 km from the town, three wheeler (taxi) would be a good option. Otherwise, there's a bus (Kandy - Pilimatalawa - Daulagala raod) you can take from the Gadaladeni junction. Then, get down at Lankatilake junction and walk 300 m to reach the temple. If you are traveling by your own vehicle or taxi, use the other road which you can go to the top of the cliff. There is parking space available.
Great temple to be with a history behind. their is a local guide near the temple who will explain you all the story behind the temple
This is a Buddhist temple complex. The view is good.This is out of Kandy town.You can visit if you have time.

We were drived from Dambulla to Kandy and made a quick detour here since it was not too far out of the way. This temple is very historical. Entrance fee was Rs 300 per adult and it was not crowded when we visited. The door to the temple itself was locked but I asked a monk to unlock it which he happily did.

You can make a walk between 3 temples, I think it is the nicest way to combine local life, temples, nature. You can take a tuc tuc from Kandy to go to the starting point, back by local bus or tuc tuc.

This temple is currently undergoing some renovation.  It is built on a huge rock.  There is a small pond.  The stupa has a door which you can go in, although the interior is small.  It is a short but steep walk from the street.

Lankatilaka Temple is another of the three "temples of the loop". It dates back to the middle of the 14th century, having been built during the reign of King Bhuvanekabahu IV, based on a plan designed by a South Indian architect named Sathapati Rayar. Inside the temple there is a large, polychrome statue of Buddha, and the ceiling and the walls of the main the main hall are adorned with Kandyan era paintings and statues. It is quiet place, no tourists here, hardly any locals and worth a short visit...
The setting was really nice. They were doing a large renovation and hence we could not see it well. Would be good once the renovations are done.

This is a Buddhist temple and renowned for its architecture and the Buddhist significant. A quick visit with about 30 minutes would be sufficient to extract all details about this place. If you are into architecture the structure of the main building will be an interest to you. However you feel the peace moment you enter the place.
One of the best and oldest temple we visited, its a must do if you hate crowd and need to check real historical places

Must see if you're taking a reserve taxi from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya, or traveling through Matale. Visited during afternoon, so it was not crowded. The Bodhi trees, records carved on rock, surrounding view and mostly the architecture of the temple make it a worthwhile visit.
Sri Lanka, the land of elephant and bhudha. Another beautiful temple situated on small Hill top overlooking beautiful paddy fields
It's worth to visit the temple while you are traveling Kandy Matale area. Not too crowded other than Poyadays

Visited here whilst on a day long trip seeing various sights. This is only a 30 to 40 minute visit to a very beautiful and peaceful temple. Very nice quiet time here during a busy hectic day. Lots of carvings and art to see and well worth the visit

Nice temple with good views on rice fields and countryside. You can easily combine with Gadaladeniya Vihara and Embekke Devalaya in a (dense) half-day trip from Kandy. Botanical garden is also on the way
This is one of the many pretty Buddhist temple here.The view from the temple also beautiful. You can spend about half hour here.
very interesting to see all the art and carvings on the wall around the temple, temple has long history and worth a visit.

We were driving from Negombo to Kandy and made a quick detour here since it was not too far out of the way. This temple is on the Rs 500 note and is very historical. Entrance fee was Rs 300 per adult and it was not crowded when we visited. The door to the temple itself was locked but I asked a monk to unlock it which he happily did.
You feel like you are in king's era. Everyone who precious history should visit this temple at least once in your life time

Our tuk tuk driver for the day brought us here, I would probly advise tuk tuk or taxi because I don’t think many or any buses go there!? Beautiful temple and the monks are so lovely explaining the history of the great temple and grounds! Lovely view aswell! Totally worth a visit for only 300Rs each!

We walked here from Embekke temple. Lovely walk through country lanes and rice fields. Friendly locals helped guide us up a short way to temple. Entry 300 rupees. Beautiful peaceful place on a hill rock with great views. Really nice inside and friendly helpful person opened temple for us. Well worth the visit if you have time. Spent about 30 minutes here.
Climb up the stone steps to see this temple in its full glory. Amazing murals and scripts etched into the rock. Like all the temples we visited, locals are happy to talk and give information.
It was a beautiful accient temple that was very calm and peacfull. Their are also many beatiful accient arts

The Lankathilaka temple is somewhat remote, but can be reached from Any within about 30 mins drive. The temple is beautiful, situated on the top of the hill will great overview over the paddy fields and the jungle. The people around are very friendly and nice, not at all chasing you if you do not want to buy anything... The best day visiting is always Poya (full moon day), and aim for the evening before dark for the best atmosphere. Highly recommended!

The temple is built on the summit of the rock called Panhalgala in the village of Rabbegamuwa, Udunuvara division of Kandy district. It can be approached from two directions, one from the Colombo-Kandy road and another from the Gampaha-Kandy road. Lankatilaka, together with another Buddhist shrine at Gadaladeniya and the Embekke Devale form an important trio possessing their individual architectural and decorative merits to attract connoisseurs and scholars from all over the world. Overlooking the eastern escarpment of the rock, the surroundings provide a magnificent panorama with distant hills, paddy fields and diverse vegetation. Apparently the site had been selected as usual for its beauty and peaceful environment, at a proper distance from bustling village life. This hamlet is well known for its traditional vocations, which are obviously part of its cultural heritage handed down from ancient times.
The place is little away from the main road, but reaching there, we found a poorly maintained area with no directions or help, totally deserted and no activity

This is a great stop on top a hill where this temple sits. There is a small admission fee so bring some cash. You're let inside by the warden / caretaker and get to take in the magic of this 1-room temple. We were the only ones there during our visit so it was VERY peaceful and a nice time to reflect.
we went three temple loop trekking we so lot of water birds, & reptile and also more interesting Embekka & gadaladeniya. this temple Location amazing,
Takes you back in time. The paintings inside the main chamber are some of the most well-preserved/well-restored I had seen on the trip around the country. Great view of the surroundings  too.

This was the second temple i came to on my hike and it was situated on top of a black rock. It was very hot climbing up the steps to the temple which was being renovated. Probably the renovation work would continue for many more months but don't let that stop you from making a visit.
This temple is about 10 km outside Kandy. Absolutely worth the travel. Only few tourists. Nice Buddha and Hindu temple. Friendly local people show you the inside of the temple.

This was our second rock Temple in the three Temple loop. Again, a relatively small site, but with with beautiful old buildings and a stunning Buddhist shrine, as well as two devalyas, one for the worship of Vishnu and the second Pattini. We were fortunate enough to arrive just before all three shrines were ritually opened in turn for following a session by ritual musicians.
A magnificent old temple dating from the 1400s Brilliant artwork in the inner rooms Fantastic location in a small little village in beautiful countryside
very old temple built on a rock . It seems that all these temples are painted white and well maintained. . there is no loitering or filth lying around . Neat and tidy

The lankathilaka temple is about 15 km from the Kandy city and is one of the most iconic temples in the region. The temple goes back 7 centuries. The ceiling painting are well preserved and are magnificent. The guide said the couple of ivory tusks you see in the inner chamber are 2000 years old and belong to the kandula elephant of king dutugamunu. The buddahs eyes are blue star Sapphires weighing more than 100 carats each and the value cannot be estimated. It's a very unique well kept temple. Must visit of Kandy
This temple is a little far out of the city but it is worth the drive over.  There are lots of paintings and statues of buddhas to see.  There is a small entry fee but it is well worth it.
Lovely place, blissful, a bit crowded.. Was really broken to see the amount of people who wait at the temple to pray..
Great views inside and outside the temple. Very tranquil. Hardly anyone there and a real gem in terms of that authentic experience
i want alone in a motorbike. Peaceful place. But when it is a poyaday or a festival day, there are more crowd and not a very good day to visit there.  It makes very beautiful view from the distance.

It's a nice temple.  Definitely a little bit out of the way.  It's very nice inside.  Though I think they should have some kind of "Traffic guard" to control the flow of people in and out the small door inside the temple.

The oldest in Sri Lanka. We were shown inside by a guide, who was happy with a small donation. Part of the building was closed. At the rear a drummer and a piper were playing, it was very atmospheric.
Very beautiful view on the top of the rock. old temple belongs to kandy period.And huge inscription in the left side of the temple. For the nature lovers, It has a three temple tracking.

Just 2 km from Kandy- Colombo(A1) main road. you have to move along Pilimatalawa -Dawlagala road. If you are interested on historical places and ancient architecture you must visit this temple. it is very calm and quiet place. Not crowded. Make sure about your wearing because it is temple. On the same way you can visit Gadaladeniya and Ambekke temples too.
One of the best places to visit along the Kandy road if you love to see the historical places.Calm and quiet.This temple is with full of historical paintings and architecture.

Not big, but very interesting and well conserved at a beautiful spot. What makes this, and the other temples around very interesting, are the combination of buddhism and hinduism   in the same place. You literally see Buddha with Shiva and Vishnu at the same altar.

Excellent architecture, beautiful countryside. Much of Pilimitalawa is very beautiful, however my evening watching the sunset with the stone temple was most beautiful. I have also been at the temple in the early hours of the day where traditional dancers and musicians practice their drums and other instruments. Very beautiful!

If taking a day tour around Kandy and the surrounding areas this is a must see. We saw 3 temples on our tour and this was by far the best. Very different to Temple of the Tooth in that it's way out and much more understated but very impressive. Amazing Buddhist-Hindu shrine inside and incredible scenery nearby. Would definitely recommend.

This place is good for you if you are interested in worshipping buddhist places. The lankathilaka temple has wood carvings from the kandyan era. They are true quality carvings. If you are a solo traveller this place would be the best.

The main door of this is claimed the largest wooden door in that era. Paintings have both Buddhist and Hindu influences. renovation works are going on. The ground can get very hot during day time, so better to bring extra socks as you have to take off shoes when entering to the temple premises.
The tiles were being changed in April 2017, but it's a very very beautiful place to visit (entry fee 300 Rs).

i could see very nice paintings inside. There is a nice budda statue which is gold painted. Good architectural work. On roof too there are very nice designs which is related to Kandy Gampola era. I got blessings too from buddhist monks. There are paintings of "Suvisi budda" (24 budda before Lord gauthama Sambudda) on walls. Nice place to photography. But they dont allow to take photograph with statues.
You can see this temple on 500 Rp. banknote next to WTC towers and I strongly prefers the monastery. Entrance fee 300 Rp. well spent on renovations. In a nearby shop I got very nice Vesak mask.
This is a very architectural temple with much to learn about its history. Locate near Kandy & must bring children to see the history of Sri Lanka.

Short distance from Kandy and bear 2 other temples , all worth visiting. All 3 temples are different and have interesting statues , paintings and history. I found the paintings on the door quite interesting. Inside the temple , the statues and paintings are really good.
Temple is under construction. Not really worth to go there. 300rp entrance fee to get into to temple
Historical sites. A person working. In the temple opened the doors to the main building at Lankatilaka temple and gave us a tour of the inside.

Makes for an interesting alternative temple visit in the countryside (combined with the other two temples in the vicinity) when the Temple of the Tooth is overrun with people. There are two entrances to the temple. The front entrance at the top of the hill on the street lined with craft shops presumably requires the 300 rupee entry fee. The rear entrance accessed from the bottom of the hill via a series of steps was free.

This site is still under archeological development. Inside there is a lovely gold painted meditating Buddha statue with standing statues against the adjacent walls. Note the beautiful small ponds containing purple water lilies. In the distance can be seen the world's tallest Buddha statue at Ranawara Temple.
we walked in to be nosey and were welcomed in to look around , the is a small museum and we got a blessing from one of the monks

column7: Emirate of Sharjah, United Arab Emirates
column11: Lankathilaka Temple is one of the oldest places to see in Kandy. you will get to see very old paintings and a beautiful statue of lord Buddha,

As this temple is situated on a high rock, the scenes from here is marvelous. A monk gave a description and the history of the temple in Sinhalese. Booklets and photos of this temple were available to buy. A paid parking was available near the entrance.

Gadaladeniya, Lankatilaka and Embekke Devale Temples comprise the Three-Temples Loop about half hour's drive from Kandy. With transport (car or tuk-tuk) they can all be visited together in ~ 2 hours and are not particularly busy. This temple, Lankatilaka, combines a Hindu Shrine and a Buddhist Shrine on the same property. Very nice to visit.
Went there after reading the reviews on trip advisor.. can be avoided.. its away from the city and if u are short of time visit the temple of tooth

We were here as they were getting ready for a big festival so they were busy whitewashing the temple and putting up lights. I think it would have been great to see during the festival and with all of the lights on at night. There's a Buddhist temple with large statues on one side and the main sanctuary has Hindu imagery. Apparently it's supposed to normally be closed to tourists, but the caretaker allowed us in.

When we arrived the main shrine room door was locked, but a priest came running upon seeing us and opened. There are 2 roads and one brings you to the bottom of the rock which means there are lots of steps to get to the top. Luckily for us we took the one that took us to the top. Being a rock temple, the rock gets hot. the place is amazing and the view is spectacular. A must visit place.

We loved this beautiful temple which we visited as part of a half day Kandy temple tour by tuk tuk arranged through our hotel for 2000LR including a tip - a great value tour. Half of this lovely serene temple is dedicated to Hinduism and half to Buddhism, built by the ruler of the day for himself and his Hindu wife. We were made to feel very welcome and shown the different shrines / places of worship. The views from the site were stunning. Beware of the VERY hot approach to the temple and grounds in bare feet! Our favourite temple of all the ones we visited around Kandy.
This is great for people who like to experience art and architecture of Kingdom of Kandy few hundred years back. This is also a popular destination among local Buddhist pilgrims.
This temple was built by King 4th Buwanekabahu..situated top of a rock. There are two roads to the temple. One is accessing to the top of the rock and other road is to the bottom.

If you have some time in Kandy, pay a visit to this beautiful temple. While the Buddhist temple was elegant and artistic, the brick-built Hindu temple in the complex was unique. Combine this tour with a visit to the Peridiya Botanical Garden.

This temple is built centuries ago by a Kandayan King.Located 30 mins away from the Kandy town and can be reachable by bus.The Entrance ticket For foreigners is LKR 300.00. This is an amazing structure and a well maintained ancient temple and its definitely worth Visiting.
It is one of the sacred places in kandy.there are lots of things to see wall paintings,Buddhas statues and many more
I was in a family trip my kids did not have a proper toilet facilities in this place.Although they were collecting funds they don't provide such facilities

It's situated just 10km from Peradeniya and easily guided by Google map. We went by motor bike journey and the first impression was amazing. The entrances like the old kandian style with the white palace like temple. You can have a better view of Peradeniya and hanthana mountain from the top. Tip.  Don't forget to have a look from wood crafts and metal crafts, they are really cheaper than kandy

It is amazing how the place is built on a rock. Great scenery around. One can by lot of crafts from the shops on the way. Refer my photos. Small problem with the park and the access road. But worths a visit
Lovely photo ops and a look into a well kept temple built on solid natural stone foundation. Crafts village just outside where tourists can pick up some local craft ware.

This temple is beautiful! Don't just visit the Hindu part of the temple (front part): some of the tourists who entered together with us, left after only seeing the Hindu part. Walk around the temple and visit the Buddhist part too! The guides where very kind and explained things about the statues and paintings. Very impressive. Nice to know: this is the temple you see on the 500 ruppees bill.
The intensity of the frescoes' colors, the riot of the figures and arabesques, the statues make this temple worth the effort of getting to it!   It's a unique piece of architecture!
Nice old tempel on the top of a hill.,with a vieuw on the rice paddies.Nice old paintings Peacful place

We walked here from Embekke temple, which took around 45 minutes, on a path through villages and farmland. Perched on top of a rock, there are great views from Lankatilika and wonderful murals inside the main shrine.
15-20 km from city, but a good place to visit. If you visiting during summers, do not forget to wear your socks, else it would be difficult to walk on heated stone around temple.
Great location, great view, great structure. Avoid in the heat of the day and you'll be walking around in barefeet, but definitely don't miss.

This historic temple is part of the "Three Temple Loop" near Kandy.   We very much enjoyed our visit and were able to view historic religious artefacts and statues.   We were lucky enough to be the only people there when we visited - a real treat.
It was bit out of kandy city,about an hour up and down,but there are 3 temples and we visited all of them.nice
If you are not tepled out - this is so lovely.But try and go early - the paving stones will really burn your feet at noon - you always have to be barefoot.
This is an old ancient temple, this is a good place to visit for history lovers. Calm quite environment with a beautiful ancient temple

Yes, as the guard pointed out, Lankatilake is depicted directly on the 500 rupee notes and deservedly so as it was probably our favourite shrine of the 3 temple loop and perhaps the most impressive temple in the district. The staff were all very kind here and the main curator spoke excellent english and was excited to point out some of his favourite murals and answer any questions we raised. Along with the jovial guard, it really made the 300 rupee entrance fee worthwhile. The Lankatilake temple was founded in 1344 (and their is a huge inscription carved into the rock about the process) and was originally 4 floors tall...till it collapsed in the 19th century. In the interior chamber was the really amazing part though from the huge ornate doors to the massive wall and ceiling paintings in the dark cavern around a huge buddha sculpture.  Would definitely recommend seeing it for yourself

In the south-western outskirts of Kandy you can visit three interesting temples at a short distance one another; take a bus or walk in the fields and tea plantations: you will discover a world totally different from the the chaos of Kandy.

The temple was closed but the soroundings are also worth watching. It's way more interesting If you are into the local culture and religion which they are very proud of. Otherwise you will be wasting your time.
A very beautiful temple situated closed to Gampola. Appx 1 hour from Kandy. If you go there you can visit Ambakke & Gadoladeniya temples too.

This temple has lesser crowd visiting it and thus we were the only people there when we visited it. The view of the mountains from the temple is amazing. This temple is also printed on the Sri Lankan 500 Rupees note.

This is located well outside Kandy, tucked away in the countryside, in the village of Rabbegamuwa. It is located on the summit of a large granite rock, called Panhalgala. You enter via the Main Street in the village, through a large roofed gate (entrance fee Rs300). The setting is as impressive as the temple and because it is out of the way there are very few tourists. If you make your way around to the far side (east) of the large white temple/image house, with sculptured elephants and other designs, you get to the entrance of the shrine. Inside is a large seated Buddha, with two huge ivory tusks either side. Make sure you look up as well to see the decorative paintings & designs, in particular the hansa puttuwa (conjoined swans), which apparently is the best presentation of its kind. Back around the western side of the temple, is the makara thorana (dragon arch) and the entrance to the Hindu shrine. If you can get the caretaker to unlock the doors, it is worth it. The vaulted brick Hindu shrine to Lord Vishnu, is wrapped around the outside of the Buddhist shrine, all in the one building. This is what makes it unique. Out of all the temples outside of Kandy, this is the one worth visiting.

From the first sight is it "just" an amasing white building, shining under the sun beams. But, it hides inside ... another old temple. We got there absolutely not knowing about it. The caretaker insisted that we go with him. We were at the beginning refusing - another "donation guy"... But after several minutes we were tired to argue and went with him. He opened the curtain with God, so I could not imagine, that there was a door... We saw another older temple Inside. It was unexpected and hence very catchy. The only thing that spoiled the impression was another "donation guy", who wanted us to pay the entrance ticket, but unlike in other temples he didnt have any tickets... So we refused saying, that we already payed the donation to the first guy (which was the truth). But at least the first guy earned it. The place is very beautiful from outside also... But have some socks prepared - rocks under the sun are too hot and there is almost no shade or grass to cool the feet...
One of the three temple complex. far off location. Not worth if you are pressed for time. good for meditation.

Nice temple but nothing extraordinary. You can reach it by bus ( Nr 644 from goods shed, going from Kandy to Pilimatalawa. The bus driver will tell you where to get out. Its only 750 m to walk to the temple) approx 32 rupies for the bus. You can even walk to Embekka Devale from there (3 km) and take a bus back to Kandy.
This place is really good if you are visiting on a weekday. because alots of people visit this place on weekends and holidays. advised to wear covering clothes.

it's a difficult place to find, especially since we were riding a hired scooter. but man, it's so peaceful and serene. and the view is stunning. one of the loveliest places. and the drive back to kandy was also quite amaZing.

Beautiful temple on a small rock. You can reach the temple within 1/2 hour from Pilimathalawa. The temple is well maintained and there are very good quality paintings and Buddha statues. There is a Siripathula carved on a stone. According to historical records the temple and the Devalaya is build on a pond which was believed to have miracles. King Buwanekaba the 4th has put up this temple in 1344.

Very popular among localites and said to be one of the 3 holy shrines in Kandy. It was big, built on a rock head of a hill and was very peaceful. We saw many birds and squirrels here. The only pain point we felt was the Rs 300 entry charge per person for foreigners. Could be a bit more reasonable

Situated 4kms away from Colombo, Kandy highway and Pilimathalawa town. This is not a crowded touristic site, but still the Architecture at it's best. Regarding the history, The temple history runs back to the Gampola Kingdom era. King Buwanekabahu IV has built this temple in 1344 AD and the temple has South Indian influence with it's architecture. There is nice hindu temple (Vishnu Devala) behind the main temple which has a roof done out of bricks which is really attractive. Visiting the site is worthwhile :)
Burning rock under my bare feet- amazing wall and ceiling paintings. People winnowing rice in the temple grounds- a memorable visit
A very important temple during the Gampola Kingdom and was once considered to husee the tooth of Buddha. Well worth a visit overlooking opaddy fields and local vilagers and vegetation.

Excellent place to see a bit of old architecture in peaceful surroundings. A bit out of the way, but worth the time. Try to combine with a visit to Gadaldeniya Temple and Ambekke Devalaya (to see the beautiful wood carvings).
beautiful place to visit specially this Buddhist temple made by clay and it's situated by beautiful place as well

This temple is also located on the same road  off Kandy road at Pilimathalawa  as Gadaladeniya.  But you need to go about 3Km more. This temple  is constructed in early 1600AD. The shrine room in this temple  is unique in that the same shrine room is dedicated to load buddha as well as Hindu deities. This is the only temple  where this unified shrine room exists. This can be attributed to the fact that the architect of this temple is a Hindu devotee from Madras. In Sri Lanka the Buddhist temples of the Anuradhapura era does not have and shrines dedicated to Hindu deities. The temples of Polonnaruwa era and later  has separate shrine within the temple premises dedicated to Hindu deities. The temple shrine room consists of many beautiful murals.
This is very nice architectural , and beautiful place at Pilimathalawa village on kandy road ,we can say its worth watching ,nice wive point
Nice views from there . Old nice temple 07/08 KM from Pilimathalawa town . Small road to reach to the temple .

Much quieter than the Temple of the Tooth, we were the only visitors at the time! This temple is circa 14th century, and is completely stunning. The staff were amazing with their explanations and became our tour guide. The views over the hills of Kandy is just gorgeous. We'd recommend this temple every time!
Just 7 Km from my parents place, not just the Temple but the surrounding is still a village where you can breath in the fresh air (once you get off the main road) . Old architecture of highest kind.
We walked from Embekka Devale, scenic tour through the village and along rice paddies. Not too strenuous, even for kids, and very rewarding.
For those who love ancient history, as well as religious pilgrimages and inspiration, not only for the Buddhist but for all

Situated on a high point the temple can be seen from many vantage points. The views from the temple are very panoramic and if you arrive at a quiet time the whole place is very tranquil and calming. Unfortunately like most attractions it can become very busy especially if descended upon by school tours. Best time to visit is early morning

Lankathilaka is a temple on a rock which is a fine example of Kandyan Architecture. The structure is majestic and really worth a visit. As the temple built on a rock avoid visiting at noon as it will be hot and difficult to walk. Pleased that the temple was maintained well. The door and the lion flag at the entrance of the temple are worth seeing too.

Lankathilaka temple has a different architecture compared to many other temples. Nice impressive structure, on top of a small hill. You need to climb up around 200 steps to reach the temple. We visited the temple while driving back from Nuwara Eliya to Colombo. This place is a little off the main roads and in the same circuit as Embekke and Galadeniya temples. Very beautiful murals inside the temple. There is a stone inscription outside. Temple dates back to 14th Century. Guide at the temple mentioned that the temple is featured on Sri Lankan 50Rs note. There is a Vishnu temple also in the backside of the same building. There is a Fee of Rs.300 for foreigners.

One of the three elements of the Temple Loop, this is an impressive temple, dating back to 1344, sitting on a hill with lovely views out over the valleys around it.  A large main building, the interior is very impressive indeed with excellent murals on show. The decorative elements are the feature here and some of the murals are quite stunning. The conjoined swans motif on the ceiling is said to be the best presentation of its kind in Asia and we wouldn't disagree.
It is closed a tiny virgin forest - "Udawatakelle" Forest Sanctuary. This Lake full of water and catch our eyes. Lovely feelings. Unbelievable.
As seen in post-cards and paintings, a beautiful temple worth visiting for the first time traveller.  Lots of history and culture in this place.

We visited this beautiful 14thC  temple together with the Gadaladeniya and the Embekke Devale as an excursion from Kandy. The Lankatilanka sits on top of a hill with stunning views in all directions. The huge rock where the temple was built is called as Panhangala Rock You climb a steep set of steps cut into the rock to reach the temple complex. Inside is a  huge Bo tree, an Audience hall and an image house with a seated Buddha statue with a Makara Torana above the image. The concept of Bodhi is depicted here by the arrangement of tree and flower design. There are gorgeous paintings from Suvisi Vivarana or the lives of the twenty four previous Buddha's in the surrounding walls. We really enjoyed visiting a truly spiritual and tranquil spot, it was a most rewarding experience and right off the tourist track.

This temple can be seen on the 500 rupees bill. Nicely decorated and rather old. I would not make a big detour just to see another temple but if it is on your way, it is certainly worth stopping. The entry fee is 300 rupees and they give you a small explanatory brochure which is nice.

The temple is located in ideal location,with a 180 degree view and beautiful surroundings. since its out of the way from kandy city its not over crowded and you can leisurely see the temple.its a wonderful experience.

The Lankatilika Temple is situated near to Peradeniya and is accessible by a tuk tuk from Kandy town. It was constructed in the fourteenth century on the site of a huge rock named Panhangala. One climbs up along rock cut steps and enters through a stone archway to view the magnificent areas of the Temple complex. The Bo tree is wonderful, as are the sections dedicated to various gods and images of the Buddha. It is fascinating to learn that gods were worshipped along with the Buddha. Appropriate dress must be worn and shoes removed when entering the Temple. We regard this as one of the great sights near to Kandy and definitely recommend visiting it.

We liked this temple complex more then the one at Gadaladeniya. You have the pay the entrance fee to the Budhist monk and he will show you the inside of the temple. His english was pretty good and we had a nice talk with him. Worth a visit. Be aware that the road to the templex complex is narrow, steep and winding. By the way, they painted the temple white, so it's not blue any more...

Build during King Wikramabahu the 3rd during Kandy kindom, Lanka thilaka Raja Maha Viharaya is one of the beautiful temples in Kandy region. The building is build with Hindu architecture while there are painting inside the temple with kandy age.

The place was calm and peaceful and located in to inside from the Kandy - Colombo main road, in a village area. As I know this was build during Kandiyan era (16, 17th Century ) and there are tremendous kandiyan wall paintings and statues. The buddha mandira (building) was located on top of a rock (But you can't have a hiking experience here ;) ) surrounding paddy fields. Don't forget to visit if are on the way to Kandy.
A quiet peaceful place.  Incredible artwork showing the mix of Hinduism and Buddhism.  Worth a couple of hours of your schedule to see something a little different.
Sri Lankathilaka temple is built on the summit of a rock named Panhalgala. Dates back to 1344. Its a world heritage site with a beautiful statue of Lord Buddha.
Lovely place - the real deal, very authentic and not designed for tourists. Lots of Buddhists praying.  Followed up by a dance concert in the next door venue which was superb!
very pretty little temple with a history back dating to the 14th  century. the lush vegetation and on the way is a mazing
Great to bus out to the three temples and walk between them for an afternoon.  Very easy to do independently.

We visited this temple as part of the three-temple-loop. It is a special temple as it has two parts, it is half Buddhist and half Hindu. Entrance is 300 rupee per person, to pay at the Buddhist part. We also found this the best place to buy some wooden souvenirs at fair prices. On the path to the temple you will find a couple of little shops. When you walk to the temple, you will find a wood carving shop at your let hand. Very friendly guy, great items and fair prices. We didn't even bother bargaining as the prices were fine already :-).

A beautiful temple hidden in the verdant hills outside Kandy.  Great views and no pesky guides hounding you for donations.  There's a very good woodworker shop directly down the hill from the temple on the right
One of the most beautiful temples we visited, so peaceful and everyone was very welcoming. Very difficult to leave!

Visited this temple second on a tour of the 3 temples from Kandy.  This was my favourite.  Perched on rock, above lovely views of paddy fields.  Hindu and Buddhist.  Puja was performed at 11, until 11;15, at which point we were allowed to enter.  Cot R300, for an adult, half for children. Made a lovely excursion.

After a drive of about 30 minutes outside of Kandy, nestled in the hills lie three beautiful, yet different temples built in the late 1500s by King Buwanekabahu IV (1341 to 1351) and his successors. The three temples, Gadaladeniya Vihara, Sri Lankathilaka Temple and Devale, and Embekke Devale, are all within a short drive of each other, close to the Kandy-Colombo Road, and easily accessed by 3-wheeler (tuktuk) or other vehicles.  The entry fee for each temple is 300 rupees or around 3 euros/dollars. I am not so sure about the walking loop, but the drive from Kandy was work it.  My driver, Lucky (077 650 8265), took me around for 10,000 rupees. It took about 3 hours and was well worth the excursion. I'd advise seeing all three temples. This temple has a very serene setting with view across the mountains.  The solid white building with ornate plasterwork was very beautiful.  Each of the temples is very different and neither of them have much interpretation available on sight.
This is a pretty place.  The drive up is high and winding.  It is a buddist temple within a hindu temple, which is pretty interesting.

These are 2 roads to this temple. You can easily go by a vehicle from 1 way & From other way you can climb the Rock though steps. I recommend this place highly. When you climbed the rock you can see lot of area from here. This temple is well maintained.

The temple is nice and calm. But what put us off was the following: 1. The person  gave us our tickets - He took the money from us, but gave us old used tickets (clearly pocketing the money for himself). When we bought the tickets, a ceremony was ongoing because of which we couldn't enter the temple. But he didnt  state this fact upfront - told us only after we bought the tickets, and then assured us it would take only 5 more minutes. Instead we had to wait for about 30 mins. 2. The temple brochure talks of many artefacts - example -  a sapphire Buddha statue. However most of these artefacts are not displayed to public. Somehow, a bad example of expectation management.

Please do spend some time to go here. It is a wonderful place. Not the easiest if you are challenged physically but make the effort, brave the stairways. Interesting as a place of worship what ever your religion and a real testament to social history and architecture. It has everything to feast your eyes and soul on. Truly peaceful if somewhat neglected.
I am a lover of all things Budhist. this beautiful temple although slightly ignored and about 15 kms from kandy is in itself a very improtant place of worship historically.

After a climb of 179 steps, we reached the temple.  Outside a drummer and pipe player were performing, while a service was underway inside After the service was over,  we were allowed into the temple and  a monk showed us the interior.   The inner sanctum has spectacular wall paintings

A lovely Buddhist shrine located quite close to that of Embekka devalaya, on top of a small hillock. Mostly visited by only the locals, one rarely finds much tourists around here. There is a lovely local handicrafts shop at one of the entrances to the temple. It was so sweet to watch the little kids in their cute white uniforms at the school attached to this viharaya. We wished we could have brought a packet of candies to distribute to the kids there. The access road to this shrine from Embekka is quite dilapidated. So expect a bumpy ride. The entrance fee to this shrine is 300SLR.

Among of the three-temple loops (Embekke, Lankatilaka and Gadaladeniya); this is my favorite. Located on the summit of rock in Udunuwara, Lankatilaka was formerly four storeys tall. One can access via two ways; the Eastern entrance or the Western entrance. If you opt with the Eastern entrance, you need to climb flight of staircase to reach up to the peak. Tiring, but it's all worth a climb the moment you reach the top. Entrance fee is Rs300 as at February 2014.

Lankatilake Viharya is located 12km from the Peradeniya bridge in Kandy district. It is built on the summit of a rock called Panhalgala and provides a magnificent panoramic view of the surrounding hills, paddy fields and the diverse vegetation around it. The building was originally four storeyed but today there is only the ground floor and a part of the first floor. The temple is built of brick and granite on an uneven rock surface with a cruciform ground plan. The architecture is a combination of the Polonnaruwa period with Indian influence. A flight of stairs cut into the rock surface of the premises leads to the main entrance of the temple. On both sides of the entrance are gajasimhas (Elephant-lion) sculptures. There is an arched passage decorated with carved Gandharva and Gaja-Lakshmi. In one of the niches there is a huge statue of Ganesha, while in another there is a statue of Vishnu, reflecting the Hindu influence. The deity Skanda can be found to the north of entrance. The passage leads to a pavilion and through it to an inner chamber. The 24 Buddhas that preceded Gautama Buddha are exquisitely painted on the walls and ceiling. In a chamber is a colossal statue of seated Buddha under a beautiful dragon arch. Near the temple are rock inscriptions in Sinhala and Tamil detailing the temple facilities and the gifts bestowed by the kings. The shoes have to be removed and kept at a place some distance away from the temple. When I visited the sun was blazing and the ground was very hot making it very painful to walk barefoot to the temple. The caretaker permits only one group at a time inside the temple. I was alone with my guide and there was no one before us. So we had a quick access to the temple. The statues of the Bhairavas as door guardians can be seen at one of the entrances and is truly impressive.

One of the Three Temples outside Kandy this is arguably the most interesting. Constructed of brick the outside temple is Hindu with heavy Southern Indian influences. The caretaker showed us round and had obvious pride in his property. The Hindu part has excellent images of the gods. The one of Ganesh was particularly fine with extremely fat belly and a white elephant head in stark contrast to the brown body. The inner temple is reached from the other end of the building. It contains the image of Buddha. The main construction material is brick. Quiet and contemplative
This was the best of the three temples we saw on the same day. The inner temple is Buddhist, the outer temple is Hindu. The view was beautiful. The guide - an old man - was very sweet.

This temple is part of the 3 temple loop.   I took a bus and started at one end and walked to the last temple through villages and forest and rice fields.   This was an amazing day!!!   And this particular temple I spoke with the monk and got an earful of information.   What a beautiful buddhist/hindu temple.

Although the visit was unplanned but quite insightful. The moment I entered the temples was asked us to leave for their prayer time! The guy who charged the ticket didn't tell us this could also happen.
Unless you have a guide who can explain some of the items in the collection, not sure you would get much from this place.  Can't say if it was good value for money as our guide paid.
A temple built on a rock surface which has a lot of Buddhist culture gathered. Situated in Pilimathalawa closer to Kandy and a good temple to visit if you are passing by.

These are the places you must see if you have enough time in your travel itinerary. The serene atmosphere, The Architecture of the big temple and Dewalaya and the most magnificent Buddha Statue in the temple is a must see. The other fact is all these major temples in  Sri lanka has its own annual pageant smiler to the Kandy Pageant. So if you wish to see one of these spectacular events you need to plan ahead about your day of arrival.
